How to Play Free Cell 

 Free Cell is a variant of solitaire. It is played on a board with three areas: the areas are four Free Cells, eight Tableau Columns, and four Foundations. In portrait orientation the Free Cells are at the top of the screen in the left half, the Foundations are at the top in the right half, and the Tableau Columns are below the Free Cells and Foundations. In landscape orientation the Free Cells are along the left edge of the screen, the Foundations are along the right edge, and the Tableau Columnns are in the middle. 

 At the start of the game, the entire 52 card deck is dealt face up into the Tableau Columns. The goal is to move all the cards into the Foundations. 

 Cards must be placed into Foundations in rank order (from Ace to King). Only one suit can be played on an individual Foundation; for example, once the Ace of Hearts is played on one of the Foundations the Two of Hearts must be the next card played on that Foundation, and so on. 

 A Free Cell is free to hold any card, but can only hold one at a time. 

 A card can be added to a Tableau Column only if it is the opposite color (red or black) and one rank lower (a two on a three, a three on a four, etc.) than the card already at the bottom of the Tableau Column. Any card can be placed on an empty Tableau Column. 

 Cards can be moved freely (one at a time) between Tableau Columns and Free Cells, but once a card is placed on a Foundation it cannot be moved again. 


About Free Cell by Conversant


 We have done a number of things to make the playing of Free Cell more enjoyable than sitting down with a deck of cards. 

 While the rules of Free Cell state that cards must be moved only one at a time, we allow the moving of a grouped sub-pile when the open spaces on the board would allow for that group to move to the new location through a series of single card moves. The sub-pile must be a group that by itself follows the rules of descending ranks of alternating colors. 

 There is an autoplay feature (turned on by default), that will move cards to the Foundations when it is certain that you no longer need that card to complete the game. Autoplay moves cards at a speed that can be changed via the Settings screen. You can not make moves of your own while an autoplay move is being made. 

 When you pick up a card or a sub-pile the places where you can 'drop' it are highlighted. Because heavy highlighting can be distracting to some players and too light of highlighting can be unnoticed by some, the strength of the highlighting can be set via a slider on the Settings screen. Slide this down to the minimum to turn off highlighting entirely. 


The Main Menu


 Continue 

 This selection only appears if you have a game that is begun but not yet completed. Select it to resume play. 

 New Game 

 This selection lets you start a new game. If there is a game already in progress it will be abandoned. 

 Settings 

 The Settings screen lets you adjust a few things about playing Free Cell. You can turn Autoplay on or off. You can adjust the animation speed of the autoplay moves. You can adjust the strength of the highlights which provide hints to speed up your playing. And you can choose from a small selection of background colors. 

 Scoring 

 Lower scores are better. For every move you make to a Tableau Column or a Free Cell, you will gain 2 points. Autoplay moves accrue 0 points, as do any moves to a Foundation Cell. Back moves are worth 1 point. Forward moves are worth 0 points.
